title: File integrity hash
author: catalinciubotariu
body_snippet:
Please add the checksums for file integrity

I have found a previous post which has the status solved but actually I'm not able to find where I can find the hash/MD5 to check the file integrity. In the archive there is no update.txt file. Is it possible to add a MD5/SHA checksum?

Thanks in advance,
Catalin

iterations.description: Add SHA256 checksums to GitHub release artifacts for download integrity verification — standard security practice, achievable via CI workflow change.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
Yes, we can start posting the checksums in a more public place.

@benwa Could the website parse the update files and show checksum/cert thumbprint data on the downloads page?

For the moment, checksums are currently available in the following places (depending on update channel and edition):
- https://mremoteng.org/update.txt
- https://mremoteng.org/update-portable.txt
- https://mremoteng.org/beta-update.txt
- https://mremoteng.org/beta-update-portable.txt
- https://mremoteng.org/dev-up...

comments.author: benwa
comments.snippet:
I should be able to get that done, will have to look into parsing the file.
UI wise, are you thinking we add it to the tooltip?
What format checksum is it?
We should also try to add it to the https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG.github.io/blob/master/_data/releases.json file for the future.  I'll update that spec after this one.

comments.author: sparerd
comments.snippet:
Either expand-div or tooltip that can be click-activated. The checksum should be easy to copy/paste.

The hash in the upgrade check files is SHA512. MSI files also have a certificate thumbprint that would be nice to include. The thumbprint is more secure than the file hash, so it would be nice to include if possible.

All these values are part of the build, so if some build automation would make this easier we could probably figure something out.

notes:
AI triage (claude): Add SHA256 checksums to GitHub release artifacts for download integrity verification — standard security practice, achievable via CI workflow change.
Approach: Add a step in the release CI workflow to compute SHA256 hashes of all release ZIPs and attach a checksums.txt file to the GitHub release. PowerShell Get-FileHash or sha256sum in the workflow.
